data.text: Are DiamondBack Bicycles Worth the Money?

Does anybody know anything about diamond back bicycles? Their website has them very very very expensive￼. Cheapest $475. Walmart and Amazon sell them for $250. I don’t understand the discrepancy of price. ￼

The Walmart bike will have a less of quality componets on it. Big box stores have a little better quality than wally world. bike shops have even better quality . My advice would be to shop second hand bikes, plenty of low use good quality bikes fo affordable rates >

data.text: When you buy a bicycle, it consists of 4 main groups; 1) Frame (40% of TP) - including seat post and forks 2) Group set (30% of TP) - Crank, cassette, shifters n etc 3) Wheelset (15% of TP) - front n back wheels 4) others (15% of TP) - racks, saddle, tyres n etc TP = total price. Percentage applicable to Touring Bike only For serious touring, we recommend a chromoly steel frame, a Shimano Deore or better gearing set and a 36 spokes wheelset. Don't go by the brand name, as they do both high and low end. I m using a Surly Long Haul Trucker with sram X9 groupset and a 26'' wheels with 36 spokes. Hope it helps
data.author: Wan Sabri

data.text: I suggest you break down type/style/material/groups/options rather than brands. 1: Type of bike. Posting on this site I assume a touring bike? Correct? 2: Frame material. For durability, options and value I believe you can’t go past steel. 3: Riding position/handlebars. Flat, drop, butterfly. This leads onto shifters. 4: Groupsets. Most common and spares / repairs easily sourced you can’t go past Shimano. I would definitely steer away from department store Shimano levels. I believe 105 is the best bang for your buck but you can go down to Sora or even Claris without major dramas. Don’t go lower. 5: Brakes. Rim or hydraulic. Quite a divisive subject. Both have pros and cons. 6: Options. Mainly racks and lights. Easier and more cost effective to get with the purchase. Everything will fit. Adding later, you can customise to suit. 7: Wheel size and width. Depending where you plan to travel and type of conditions will help you decide. Consider what you plan to do, how and where you will ride. This will help to answer each criteria. This will narrow down and focus on one or two bikes in each brand. You can then shop around new or pre-loved. A lot to consider and digest but worthwhile. Ask questions. Good luck and happy riding.
data.author: Scott Thompson

data.text: 4: Groupsets. My original post only included road groups. For mtb groups I believe XT is best bang for your buck. Deore and Alivio are good, even down to Tourney but don’t go lower.

data.text: Hi, Lisa- the difference between a wal-mart bike and a bike store bike will likely be the quality of the components (brakes, crank, handlebars, gears...) and the quality of the workmanship-- A wal-mart bike will be comparably easy to break and difficult to fix, but a high-end bike might have design features in the components that will help you adjust them more easily; sometimes with your bare hands. If the crank (two front gears and arms where pedals attach) on a wal-mart bike looks like 500 of them were stamped out in an hour in a factory, it's probably because 500 of them were stamped out in an hour in a factory vs. being inspected and filed and re-checked by a human being.

data.text: This is very much, you will get what you pay for. Of course, if you're looking for a top end racer, an extra thousand dollars will only give you negligable (or marginal) gains - probably so little you wouldn't even notice. However, at the opposite end of the market, spending more will give you enormous improvements in quality and performance. If you're planning to become a proper cyclist, then buying a supermarket cheapie, will likely cost you more in the long run, than buying from a reputable bike shop, who should help you decide exactly what you need and get the best value for money, within your financial limits. Very cheap bikes have very cheap components and these will not last long - best to spend more on a bike with decent components, in order to avoid needing replacements, after only a few months.

data.text: The bike take away here and what most people are offering is that $475 is still considered below entry level, even if it's a high price for a department store bike. These bikes are made to a price point and even the nicer ones suffer from plastic bearing races that need constant adjustment, poor assembly, etc. My experience with Magna's warranty was amazing. I sent them pics of the issues and they promptly sent me parts for my kids'bikes, but didn't cover labor and the labor at the bike shop was nearly the cost of the bike. If you are constrained by a certain price point, used is an option if you're knowledgeable/have a knowledgeable friend and aren't afraid to learn maintenance. If you can stretch the budget a newer bike from a bike shop that will fit you, do a free initial tuneup after purchase and support later. Something like this will hold value, last an eternity and the bike shop will be there for maintenance and warranty issues should they arrive.

data.text: The brand name has almost nothing to do with bike quality since brands span huge price ranges. These days rich bicycle fanatics might buy bikes with the top two shimano groups but normal upper middle class fanatics get bikes with the 105 or Tiagra group. These medium price bikes typically have aluminum frames and carbon forks and are masterpieces of functional elegance. Carbon frames are more expensive. Steel is found on only cheap or very expensive bikes. So called high-ten steel (high tensile) actually isn't high compared to good steel and the bikes are cheap, heavy and found in Walmart. Quality steel bikes are made from steel that's 3 to 7 times higher tension than high-ten steel and are light weight but are as expensive as carbon frames. If you know enough about bikes and their maintenance online purchases can be a decent option. In your case however a bike shop is the best place to go. First you should think about if you want a hybrid, gravel, road style.
